The line $M N$ belongs to the section plane. Point $Q$ -

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d960854a9c9c598cc600g-23.jpg?height=357&width=509&top_left_y=130&top_left_x=1416)
is the intersection of lines $M N$ and $A C$. In the plane of the lateral face ATC, draw the line $T P \| A C$, where $P$ lies on the line $M N$. Triangles $T P N$ and $C Q N$ are similar, and $\frac{T P}{Q C}=\frac{T N}{N C}=\frac{1}{3}$, triangles $Q M A$ and $P M T$ are equal, $T P=Q A=a / 2$.

In the base plane $A B C$, connect points $Q$ and $F$, point

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d960854a9c9c598cc600g-23.jpg?height=420&width=611&top_left_y=521&top_left_x=1408)
K - the intersection of lines $Q D$ and $A B$. In triangle $A B C$, draw the midline $F S$. Triangles $Q A K$ and $F S K$ are equal, $S K=K A=a / 4$.

Quadrilateral $M N F K$ is the desired section

Find the angle of inclination of the section plane to the base plane. These planes intersect along the line $Q F$. From points $H$ and $A$, draw perpendiculars $H L$ and $A E$ to the line $Q F \cdot \frac{H D}{A D}=\frac{H L}{A E}=\frac{1}{3}$. Denote $H L=x$. Then $A E=3 x$.

Consider triangle $Q K A$. We have

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d960854a9c9c598cc600g-23.jpg?height=420&width=620&top_left_y=1389&top_left_x=1363)
$Q A=a / 2, A K=a / 4, \angle Q A K=120^{\circ} . \quad$ By the cosine theorem, we get $Q K^{2}=\frac{a^{2}}{4}+\frac{a^{2}}{16}+\frac{a^{2}}{8}=\frac{7 a^{2}}{16}, Q K=\frac{a \sqrt{7}}{4}$. Calculating the area of triangle $Q K A$, we have $S_{Q K A}=\frac{1}{2} Q K \cdot 3 x, S_{Q K A}=\frac{1}{2} Q A \cdot A K \sin 60^{\circ}, Q K \cdot 3 x=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} Q A \cdot A K, \frac{3 \sqrt{7}}{4} x=\frac{a \sqrt{3}}{16}, x=\frac{a}{4 \sqrt{21}}$.

Let $\varphi$ be the angle between the section plane and the base plane. Then from triangle $O H L$ we have $\operatorname{tg} \varphi=\frac{O H}{H L}=\frac{R}{3 x}=\frac{4 R \sqrt{21}}{3 a}=\sqrt{14}, \cos \varphi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{15}}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d960854a9c9c598cc600g-23.jpg?height=339&width=396&top_left_y=2212&top_left_x=1481)

Find the area of the projection of the section on the base plane.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S_{n p}=S_{A B C}-S_{K B F}-S_{A K M_{1}}-S_{D C N_{1}}-S_{A M_{1} N_{1} C}= \\
& =S_{A B C}\left(1-\frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3}-\frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{7}{8}\right)=\frac{a^{2} \sqrt{3}}{24} . \\
& S_{c e 4}=\frac{S_{n p}}{\cos \varphi}=\frac{a^{2} \sqrt{3}}{24 \cos \varphi}=\frac{16 \sqrt{5}}{8}=2 \sqrt{5} .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d960854a9c9c598cc600g-24.jpg?height=369&width=477&top_left_y=201&top_left_x=1415)

Answer: $2 \sqrt{5}$.
informal_statement:
5. Find all values of the parameter $a$ for which the equation $(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}-\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}=(6 a-14) \cos x+2 \sin ^{2} x-4 a^{2}+14 a-2 \quad$ has $\quad$ two distinct solutions on the interval $\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{3} ; \pi\right]$. Specify these solutions for each found $a$.

Solution: $\quad(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}-\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}=(6 a-14) \cos x+2 \sin ^{2} x-4 a^{2}+14 a-2 \Leftrightarrow$ $(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}+\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a=\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}+6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1 \Leftrightarrow$ Consider the function $f(t)=t^{7}+t$. The function $f(t)$ is increasing on the entire number line. Let $u=\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a, \quad v=6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1$. Then we have the equation $f(u)=f(v)$, and due to the strict monotonicity of the function $f$, we arrive at the equation $u=v$, i.e., $\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a=6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1$. The last equation is equivalent to the following $\cos ^{2} x-(3 a-7) \cos x+2 a^{2}-7 a=0$. It is necessary to find all values of the parameter $a$ for which this equation has two distinct solutions on the interval $\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{3} ; \pi\right]$. Let's make the substitution: $y=\cos x$. We arrive at the equation $y^{2}-(3 a-7) y+2 a^{2}-7 a=0$. For the condition of the problem to be satisfied, one root of this equation must belong to the interval $[-0.5 ; 1)$, and the second, if it exists, must not belong to the interval $[-1 ; 1]$, or this equation must have two distinct solutions belonging to the set $[-1 ;-0.5) \cup\{1\}$. The discriminant of the equation $D=(3 a-7)^{2}-8 a^{2}+28 a=(a-7)^{2}$. The only solution will be at $a=7$, which is the solution $y=7$. In all other cases, we have two distinct solutions $y_{1}=2 a-7$ and $y_{2}=a$.

1) $-0.5 \leq 2 a-71 \Rightarrow a \in[3.25 ; 4), \quad \cos x=2 a-7, x_{1}=\arccos (2 a-7)$, $x_{2}=-\arccos (2 a-7)$.
2) $-0.5 \leq a1 \Rightarrow a \in[-0.5 ; 1), \cos x=a, x_{1}=\arccos (a), x_{2}=-\arccos (a)$. The equation cannot have two distinct solutions belonging to the set $[-1 ;-0.5) \cup\{1\}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 5. Find all values of the parameter $a$ for which the equation $(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}-\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}=(6 a-14) \cos x+2 \sin ^{2} x-4 a^{2}+14 a-2 \quad$ has $\quad$ two distinct solutions on the interval $\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{3} ; \pi\right]$. Specify these solutions for each found $a$.

Solution: $\quad(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}-\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}=(6 a-14) \cos x+2 \sin ^{2} x-4 a^{2}+14 a-2 \Leftrightarrow$ $(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}+\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a=\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}+6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1 \Leftrightarrow$ Consider the function $f(t)=t^{7}+t$. The function $f(t)$ is increasing on the entire number line. Let $u=\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a, \quad v=6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1$. Then we have the equation $f(u)=f(v)$, and due to the strict monotonicity of the function $f$, we arrive at the equation $u=v$, i.e., $\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a=6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1$. The last equation is equivalent to the following $\cos ^{2} x-(3 a-7) \cos x+2 a^{2}-7 a=0$. It is necessary to find all values of the parameter $a$ for which this equation has two distinct solutions on the interval $\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{3} ; \pi\right]$. Let's make the substitution: $y=\cos x$. We arrive at the equation $y^{2}-(3 a-7) y+2 a^{2}-7 a=0$. For the condition of the problem to be satisfied, one root of this equation must belong to the interval $[-0.5 ; 1)$, and the second, if it exists, must not belong to the interval $[-1 ; 1]$, or this equation must have two distinct solutions belonging to the set $[-1 ;-0.5) \cup\{1\}$. The discriminant of the equation $D=(3 a-7)^{2}-8 a^{2}+28 a=(a-7)^{2}$. The only solution will be at $a=7$, which is the solution $y=7$. In all other cases, we have two distinct solutions $y_{1}=2 a-7$ and $y_{2}=a$. -/
/- 5. Find all values of the parameter $a$ for which the equation $(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}-\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}=(6 a-14) \cos x+2 \sin ^{2} x-4 a^{2}+14 a-2 \quad$ has $\quad$ two distinct solutions on the interval $\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{3} ; \pi\right]$. Specify these solutions for each found $a$.

Solution: $\quad(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}-\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}=(6 a-14) \cos x+2 \sin ^{2} x-4 a^{2}+14 a-2 \Leftrightarrow$ $(\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a)^{7}+\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a=\left(6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1\right)^{7}+6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1 \Leftrightarrow$ Consider the function $f(t)=t^{7}+t$. The function $f(t)$ is increasing on the entire number line. Let $u=\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a, \quad v=6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1$. Then we have the equation $f(u)=f(v)$, and due to the strict monotonicity of the function $f$, we arrive at the equation $u=v$, i.e., $\cos 2 x+14 \cos x-14 a=6 a \cos x-4 a^{2}-1$. The last equation is equivalent to the following $\cos ^{2} x-(3 a-7) \cos x+2 a^{2}-7 a=0$. It is necessary to find all values of the parameter $a$ for which this equation has two distinct solutions on the interval $\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{3} ; \pi\right]$. Let's make the substitution: $y=\cos x$. We arrive at the equation $y^{2}-(3 a-7) y+2 a^{2}-7 a=0$. For the condition of the problem to be satisfied, one root of this equation must belong to the interval $[-0.5 ; 1)$, and the second, if it exists, must not belong to the interval $[-1 ; 1]$, or this equation must have two distinct solutions belonging to the set $[-1 ;-0.5) \cup\{1\}$. The discriminant of the equation $D=(3 a-7)^{2}-8 a^{2}+28 a=(a-7)^{2}$. The only solution will be at $a=7$, which is the solution $y=7$. In all other cases, we have two distinct solutions $y_{1}=2 a-7$ and $y_{2}=a$.

1) $-0.5 \leq 2 a-71 \Rightarrow a \in[3.25 ; 4), \quad \cos x=2 a-7, x_{1}=\arccos (2 a-7)$, $x_{2}=-\arccos (2 a-7)$.
2) $-0.5 \leq a1 \Rightarrow a \in[-0.5 ; 1), \cos x=a, x_{1}=\arccos (a), x_{2}=-\arccos (a)$. The equation cannot have two distinct solutions belonging to the set $[-1 ;-0.5) \cup\{1\}$. -/
theorem algebra_257427 {a : ℝ} (ha : a ≠ 7) :
    {x | x ∈ Icc (-2 * π / 3) π ∧ (cos (2 * x) + 14 * cos x - 14 * a) ^ 7 -
      (6 * a * cos x - 4 * a ^ 2 - 1) ^ 7 = (6 * a - 14) * cos x + 2 * (sin x) ^ 2 -
      4 * a ^ 2 + 14 * a - 2}.encard = 2 ↔ a = 2 * sqrt 5 := by

informal_statement:
Prove that for $a, b > 0$ and $b \neq 1$, the following inequality holds:
\[
\int_1^b a^{\log_b x} \, dx > \ln b
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real

/- Prove that for $a, b > 0$ and $b \neq 1$, the following inequality holds:
\[
\int_1^b a^{\log_b x} \, dx > \ln b
\] -/
theorem calculus_785 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (h₁ : b ≠ 1) :
    ∫ x in (1)..b, a^(logb b x) > logb e b := by

soln_description:
5. Suppose not all numbers are colored blue. Then there is a number, say $k$, that is not blue. We will now derive a contradiction.

Without loss of generality, we may assume that $k$ is red. Since all odd numbers are blue, $k$ must be even, say $k=2 m$ with $m \geqslant 1$. From the second requirement, it follows that $8 m$ is also red. From the third requirement, it follows that at least one of the numbers $8 m+2$ and $8 m+4$ is red. However, $2 m+1$ is odd and thus blue, so according to the second requirement, $8 m+4=4 \cdot(2 m+1)$ is also blue. Therefore, $8 m+2$ must be red.

Due to the third requirement, $8 m-2$ must have the same color as $8 m$ or $8 m+2$. Since $8 m$ and $8 m+2$ are both red, $8 m-2$ must also be red. Since $8 m$ and $8 m-2$ are red, the third requirement also implies that $8 m-4$ must be red. The second requirement now gives that $(8 m-4) / 4=2 m-1$ is also red. But this is impossible because $2 m-1$ is odd, and thus blue.

We see that a contradiction arises if we assume that there is a number that is not blue. Therefore, it must be that all numbers are blue.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Bas has assigned a color to each positive integer. He had various colors at his disposal. His coloring meets the following requirements:

- each odd number is colored blue;
- each number $n$ has the same color as $4n$;
- each number $n$ has the same color as at least one of the numbers $n+2$ and $n+4$.

Prove that Bas has colored all numbers blue. -/
theorem number_theory_172836 (f : ℕ → Finset ℕ) (h₀ : ∀ n, Odd n → f n = {1})
    (h₁ : ∀ n, f n = f (4 * n)) (h₂ : ∀ n, f n = f (n + 2) ∨ f n = f (n + 4)) :
    ∀ n, 0 < n → f n = {1} := by

soln_description: Solution. The fraction $\frac{93}{91}$ needs to be represented as the sum of two fractions $\frac{a}{7}$ and $\frac{b}{13}$, that is, $\frac{93}{91}=\frac{a}{7}+\frac{b}{13}=\frac{13 a+7 b}{91}$. Therefore, $93=13 a+7 b$, or $13 a=93-7 b, a, b \in \mathbb{N}$. Clearly, $b \geq 1$, so $13 a \leq 93-7 \cdot 1=86$, from which we get $a \leq 6$. From $93=13 a+7 b$ it follows that $7 b=93-13 a$, and since 7 is a divisor of $7 b$, 7 must also be a divisor of 93-13a. By direct verification, for $a \leq 6$ only when $a=5$ the number $93-13 a=28$ is divisible by 7. Finally, for $a=5$ we have $b=4$, so the desired representation is $\frac{93}{91}=\frac{5}{7}+\frac{4}{13}$.
informal_statement: 2. Represent the fraction $\frac{93}{91}$ as a sum of two positive fractions whose denominators are 7 and 13.
informal_proof:
We are given two positive rational numbers \(x\) and \(y\), such that their sum is \(93/91\), the denominator of \(x\) is \(7\), and the denominator of \(y\) is \(13\). We aim to show that \(x = 5/7\) and \(y = 4/13\).

1.  **Representing \(x\) and \(y\) in terms of numerators and denominators:**
    By definition, any rational number can be expressed as the ratio of its numerator to its denominator. Thus, we have:
    \[ x = \frac{x.\text{num}}{x.\text{den}} \]
    \[ y = \frac{y.\text{num}}{y.\text{den}} \]

2.  **Incorporating the given denominators:**
    We are given that \(x.\text{den} = 7\) and \(y.\text{den} = 13\). Substituting these values into the above expressions, we get:
    \[ x = \frac{x.\text{num}}{7} \]
    \[ y = \frac{y.\text{num}}{13} \]

3.  **Transforming the sum equation:**
    We are given the condition \(x + y = 93/91\). Substituting our simplified expressions for \(x\) and \(y\) into this equation, we obtain:
    \[ \frac{x.\text{num}}{7} + \frac{y.\text{num}}{13} = \frac{93}{91} \]
    To clear the denominators, we can multiply the entire equation by the least common multiple of \(7, 13,\) and \(91\), which is \(91\). Note that \(91 = 7 \times 13\).
    Multiplying by \(91\) gives:
    \[ 91 \left( \frac{x.\text{num}}{7} \right) + 91 \left( \frac{y.\text{num}}{13} \right) = 91 \left( \frac{93}{91} \right) \]
    \[ 13 \cdot x.\text{num} + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \]

4.  **Formulating the integer Diophantine equation:**
    Since the numerators \(x.\text{num}\) and \(y.\text{num}\) are integers, the equation derived above is a linear Diophantine equation in integers:
    \[ 13 \cdot x.\text{num} + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \]

5.  **Establishing positivity of numerators:**
    We are given that \(x > 0\). Since \(x = x.\text{num}/7\) and the denominator \(7\) is positive, it must be that the numerator \(x.\text{num}\) is also positive. Therefore, \(x.\text{num} > 0\).
    Similarly, we are given that \(y > 0\). Since \(y = y.\text{num}/13\) and the denominator \(13\) is positive, it must be that the numerator \(y.\text{num}\) is also positive. Therefore, \(y.\text{num} > 0\).

6.  **Solving the Diophantine equation for positive integers:**
    We need to find positive integer solutions for \(x.\text{num}\) and \(y.\text{num}\) in the equation \(13 \cdot x.\text{num} + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93\).
    Since \(x.\text{num} > 0\), we know \(x.\text{num} \geq 1\). From \(13 \cdot x.\text{num} = 93 - 7 \cdot y.\text{num}\), and since \(y.\text{num} \geq 1\), we have \(13 \cdot x.\text{num} \leq 93 - 7 \cdot 1 = 86\). This implies \(x.\text{num} \leq 86/13 \approx 6.61\). So, \(x.\text{num}\) must be an integer between \(1\) and \(6\) inclusive.

    Let's test possible integer values for \(x.\text{num}\) in this range:
    *   If \(x.\text{num} = 1\): \(13(1) + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 80\). No integer solution for \(y.\text{num}\).
    *   If \(x.\text{num} = 2\): \(13(2) + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 26 + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 67\). No integer solution for \(y.\text{num}\).
    *   If \(x.\text{num} = 3\): \(13(3) + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 39 + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 54\). No integer solution for \(y.\text{num}\).
    *   If \(x.\text{num} = 4\): \(13(4) + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 52 + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 41\). No integer solution for \(y.\text{num}\).
    *   If \(x.\text{num} = 5\): \(13(5) + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 65 + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 28 \Rightarrow y.\text{num} = 4\). This is a valid positive integer solution.
    *   If \(x.\text{num} = 6\): \(13(6) + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 78 + 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 93 \Rightarrow 7 \cdot y.\text{num} = 15\). No integer solution for \(y.\text{num}\).

    The unique positive integer solution to the Diophantine equation is \(x.\text{num} = 5\) and \(y.\text{num} = 4\).

7.  **Reconstructing \(x\) and \(y\):**
    Now we substitute these values back into our expressions for \(x\) and \(y\):
    \[ x = \frac{x.\text{num}}{7} = \frac{5}{7} \]
    \[ y = \frac{y.\text{num}}{13} = \frac{4}{13} \]

8.  **Conclusion:**
    Thus, we have shown that \(x = 5/7\) and \(y = 4/13\), satisfying all the given conditions.

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Represent the fraction $\frac{93}{91}$ as a sum of two positive fractions whose denominators are 7 and 13. -/
theorem number_theory_240624 (x y : ℚ) (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (h : x + y = 93 / 91) (h1 : x.den = 7) (h2 : y.den = 13) :
    x = 5 / 7 ∧ y = 4 / 13 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_240624 (x y : ℚ) (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (h : x + y = 93 / 91) (h1 : x.den = 7) (h2 : y.den = 13) :
    x = 5 / 7 ∧ y = 4 / 13 := by
  have eq1 : x = x.num / x.den := by
    rw [Rat.num_div_den x]
  have eq2 : y = y.num / y.den := by
    rw [Rat.num_div_den y]
  rw [h1] at eq1
  rw [h2] at eq2
  rw [eq1, eq2] at h 
  have eq3 : (x.num : ℚ) * 13 + (y.num : ℚ) * 7 = 93 := by 
    field_simp at h ⊢
    nlinarith 
  have eq4 : (x.num : ℤ) * 13 + (y.num : ℤ) * 7 = 93 := by 
    exact_mod_cast eq3

  have hx5 : x.num > 0 := by 
    have hx_pos : x > 0 := hx 
    rw [eq1] at hx_pos 
    have : (x.num : ℚ) / (7 : ℚ) > 0 := by linarith 
    have hx2 : (x.num : ℚ) > 0 := by 
      apply div_pos_iff.mp at this 
      cases this with 
      | inl h1 => linarith 
      | inr h2 => 
        linarith 
    exact_mod_cast hx2 

  have hy6 : y.num > 0 := by 
    have hy_pos : y > 0 := hy
    rw [eq2] at hy_pos
    have : (y.num : ℚ) / (13 : ℚ) > 0 := by linarith 
    have hy2 : (y.num : ℚ) > 0 := by 
      apply div_pos_iff.mp at this 
      cases this with 
      | inl h1 => linarith 
      | inr h2 => 
        linarith 
    exact_mod_cast hy2 

  have hx5h : x = 5 / 7 := by 
    have h7 : x.num = 5 := by 
      omega 
    rw [eq1] 
    rw [h7] 
    all_goals norm_num

  have hy8h : y = 4 / 13 := by 
    have h7 : y.num = 4 := by 
      omega 
    rw [eq2] 
    rw [h7] 
    all_goals norm_num 
  exact ⟨hx5h, hy8h⟩

soln_description:
Solution. By appearance, this equation is not linear, as it contains the product of the sought function $y$ and its derivative $y^{\prime}$. However, if we consider $x$ as a function of $y$, then, taking into account that

$$
y^{\prime}=\frac{1}{x^{\prime}}
$$

we obtain the linear equation

$$
x^{\prime}=x+y
$$

Let's apply the substitution

$$
x=u v
$$

then

$$
x^{\prime}=u^{\prime} v+u v^{\prime}
$$

Substituting these expressions into equation (B), we get

$$
u^{\prime} v+u v^{\prime}=u v+y \text { or } u^{\prime} v+u\left(v^{\prime}-v\right)=y \text {. }
$$

Choose the function $v \neq 0$ so that the coefficient of $u$ in the last equation becomes zero

$$
v^{\prime}-v=0, \cdot \frac{d v}{d y}-v=0, \frac{d v}{v}=d y
$$

Integrating, we get

$$
\ln v=y, v=e^{y}
$$

Substituting this value into equation (C), due to equality (D), we find

$$
\begin{gathered}
e^{y} \frac{d u}{d y}=y, d u=y e^{-y} d y \\
u=\int y e^{-y} d y=-y e^{-y}-e^{-y}+C
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, the general solution of equation (B) is:

$$
x=u v=\left(-y e^{-y}-e^{-y}+C\right) e^{y} \text { or } x=-y-1+C e^{y}
$$

Assuming $x=-1$ and $y=0$, we get $-1=-1+C$, i.e., $C=0$.

Therefore, the sought particular solution is

$$
y=-(x+1)
$$
informal_statement:
Example 4. Find the solution of the equation

$$
(x+y) y^{\prime}=1
$$

satisfying the initial condition: $y=0$ when $x=-1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 4. Find the solution of the equation

$$
(x+y) y^{\prime}=1
$$

satisfying the initial condition: $y=0$ when $x=-1$. -/
theorem calculus_166061 (y : ℝ → ℝ) (hy : Differentiable ℝ y)
    (h : ∀ x, (x + y x) * deriv y x = 1) (h0 : y (-1) = 0) :
    ∀ x, y x = -(x + 1) := by

informal_statement: Let $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ be positive numbers such that $ \frac { 1 } { a ^ { 3 } } = \frac { 512 } { b ^ { 3 } } = \frac { 125 } { c ^ { 3 } } = \frac { d } { ( a + b + c ) ^ { 3 } } $. Find $d$.
informal_proof:
We are given the following conditions for positive real numbers \(a, b, c, d\):
1.  \(0 < a, 0 < b, 0 < c, 0 < d\)
2.  \(\frac{1}{a^3} = \frac{512}{b^3}\)
3.  \(\frac{512}{b^3} = \frac{125}{c^3}\)
4.  \(\frac{125}{c^3} = \frac{d}{(a+b+c)^3}\)

Our goal is to find the value of \(d\). We will proceed by establishing relationships between \(a, b, c\) and then using these to solve for \(d\).

**Step 1: Express \(b^3\) in terms of \(a^3\).**
From the first equality, \(\frac{1}{a^3} = \frac{512}{b^3}\).
Since \(a > 0\) and \(b > 0\), it follows that \(a^3 > 0\) and \(b^3 > 0\). We can cross-multiply without issue:
\(b^3 = 512 \cdot a^3\).

**Step 2: Express \(b\) in terms of \(a\).**
We have \(b^3 = 512 \cdot a^3\). This can be rewritten as \(b^3 - 512 a^3 = 0\).
We recognize \(512\) as \(8^3\), so the equation becomes \(b^3 - (8a)^3 = 0\).
Using the difference of cubes factorization, \(x^3 - y^3 = (x-y)(x^2+xy+y^2)\), we get:
\((b - 8a)(b^2 + 8ab + 64a^2) = 0\).
This implies either \(b - 8a = 0\) or \(b^2 + 8ab + 64a^2 = 0\).
Let's analyze the second factor: \(b^2 + 8ab + 64a^2\).
Since \(a > 0\) and \(b > 0\), we know that \(a^2 > 0\), \(b^2 > 0\), and \(ab > 0\). Therefore, each term in the sum \(b^2 + 8ab + 64a^2\) is strictly positive.
Thus, \(b^2 + 8ab + 64a^2 > 0\).
Since the second factor is strictly positive, it cannot be zero. Consequently, the first factor must be zero:
\(b - 8a = 0 \implies b = 8a\).

**Step 3: Express \(c^3\) in terms of \(a^3\).**
From the second equality, \(\frac{512}{b^3} = \frac{125}{c^3}\).
Substitute \(b^3 = 512 a^3\) (from Step 1) into this equation:
\(\frac{512}{512 a^3} = \frac{125}{c^3}\).
Simplify the left side:
\(\frac{1}{a^3} = \frac{125}{c^3}\).
Since \(a > 0\) and \(c > 0\), \(a^3 > 0\) and \(c^3 > 0\). Cross-multiplying gives:
\(c^3 = 125 \cdot a^3\).

**Step 4: Express \(c\) in terms of \(a\).**
We have \(c^3 = 125 \cdot a^3\). This can be rewritten as \(c^3 - 125 a^3 = 0\).
We recognize \(125\) as \(5^3\), so the equation becomes \(c^3 - (5a)^3 = 0\).
Using the difference of cubes factorization:
\((c - 5a)(c^2 + 5ac + 25a^2) = 0\).
Similar to Step 2, we analyze the second factor: \(c^2 + 5ac + 25a^2\).
Since \(a > 0\) and \(c > 0\), we know that \(a^2 > 0\), \(c^2 > 0\), and \(ac > 0\). Therefore, each term in the sum \(c^2 + 5ac + 25a^2\) is strictly positive.
Thus, \(c^2 + 5ac + 25a^2 > 0\).
Since the second factor is strictly positive, it cannot be zero. Therefore, the first factor must be zero:
\(c - 5a = 0 \implies c = 5a\).

**Step 5: Express \((a + b + c)\) in terms of \(a\).**
Substitute the relations \(b = 8a\) (from Step 2) and \(c = 5a\) (from Step 4) into the expression \(a + b + c\):
\(a + b + c = a + 8a + 5a = 14a\).

**Step 6: Express \((a + b + c)^3\) in terms of \(a^3\).**
Cube both sides of the result from Step 5:
\((a + b + c)^3 = (14a)^3 = 14^3 a^3 = 2744 a^3\).

**Step 7: Solve for \(d\).**
From the third given equality, \(\frac{125}{c^3} = \frac{d}{(a+b+c)^3}\).
Substitute \(c^3 = 125 a^3\) (from Step 3) and \((a + b + c)^3 = 2744 a^3\) (from Step 6) into this equation:
\(\frac{125}{125 a^3} = \frac{d}{2744 a^3}\).
Simplify the left side:
\(\frac{1}{a^3} = \frac{d}{2744 a^3}\).
Since \(a > 0\), \(a^3\) is non-zero, so we can multiply both sides by \(2744 a^3\):
\(2744 = d\).

Thus, we have found that \(d = 2744\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{2744}\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ be positive numbers such that $ \frac { 1 } { a ^ { 3 } } = \frac { 512 } { b ^ { 3 } } = \frac { 125 } { c ^ { 3 } } = \frac { d } { ( a + b + c ) ^ { 3 } } $. Find $d$. -/
theorem algebra_13981 {a b c d : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h1 : 1 / a^3 = 512 / b^3) (h2 : 512 / b^3 = 125 / c^3) (h3 : 125 / c^3 = d / (a + b + c)^3) :
    d = 2744 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_13981 {a b c d : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h1 : 1 / a^3 = 512 / b^3) (h2 : 512 / b^3 = 125 / c^3) (h3 : 125 / c^3 = d / (a + b + c)^3) :
    d = 2744 := by
  have eq1 : b^3 = 512 * a^3 := by
    have h1' : 1 / a^3 = 512 / b^3 := h1
    have ha3_pos : 0 < a^3 := by positivity
    have hb3_pos : 0 < b^3 := by positivity
    field_simp at h1' ⊢
    nlinarith [h1']
  have eq2 : b = 8 * a := by
    have h : b^3 = 512 * a^3 := eq1
    have h1 : b^3 - 512 * a^3 = 0 := by linarith
    have h2 : b^3 - 512 * a^3 = (b - 8 * a) * (b^2 + 8 * a * b + 64 * a^2) := by
      ring_nf
    rw [h2] at h1
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 h1) with h3 h4
    · linarith
    · -- Now we need to show that the quadratic factor is non zero for positive a, b
      have h5 : b^2 + 8 * a * b + 64 * a^2 > 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_pos_of_pos ha, sq_pos_of_pos hb, mul_pos ha hb, sq_nonneg (b - 8 * a)]
      linarith [h5, show b^2 + 8 * a * b + 64 * a^2 ≥ 0 by nlinarith]
  have eq3 : c^3 = 125 * a^3 := by
    have h2' : 512 / b^3 = 125 / c^3 := h2
    rw [show b^3 = 512 * a ^ 3 by linarith [eq1]] at h2'
    have ha3_pos : 0 < a^3 := by positivity
    have hc3_pos : 0 < c^3 := by positivity
    field_simp at h2' ⊢
    nlinarith [h2', ha3_pos, hc3_pos]
  have eq4 : c = 5 * a := by
    have h5 : c^3 - 125 * a^3 = 0 := by
      linarith [eq3]
    have h6 : c^3 - 125 * a^3 = (c - 5 * a) * (c^2 + 5 * a * c + 25 * a^2) := by
      ring_nf
    rw [h6] at h5
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 h5) with h7 h8
    · -- Case where c - 5 * a = 0
      linarith
    · -- Now we need to show that the quadratic factor is non zero for positive a, c
      have h5 : c^2 + 5 * a * c + 25 * a^2 > 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_pos_of_pos ha, sq_pos_of_pos hc, mul_pos ha hc, sq_nonneg (c - 5 * a)]
      linarith [h5, show c^2 + 5 * a * c + 25 * a^2 ≥ 0 by nlinarith]
  have eq5 : a + b + c = 14 * a := by
    nlinarith [eq2, eq4]
  have eq6 : (a + b + c) ^ 3 = 2744 * a^3 := by
    rw [eq5]
    ring_nf
  have eq7 : d = 2744 := by
    have h3' : 125 / c^3 = d / (a + b + c) ^ 3 := h3
    rw [show c ^ 3 = 125 * a ^ 3 by linarith [eq3], eq6] at h3'
    have ha3_pos : 0 < a^3 := by positivity
    field_simp at h3' ⊢
    nlinarith [h3', sq_pos_of_pos ha, sq_pos_of_pos hd, mul_pos ha hd]
  linarith [eq7]

soln_description:
Solution.

First, let's sketch the curve $y=|x-2|+|3-x|$.

For $x<2$, $y=2-x+3-x=5-2x$.

For $2 \leq x \leq 3$, $y=x-2+3-x=1$.

For $x>3$, $y=x-2-3+x=2x-5$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_30_d793ff9f9da41a4dd093g-06.jpg?height=780&width=1031&top_left_y=227&top_left_x=661)

The equation $|x-2|+|3-x|=a$ has exactly two solutions for those values of $a$ for which the line $y=a$ intersects the curve at exactly two points, i.e., for $a>1$.
informal_statement:
2. For which real numbers $a$ does the equation

$$
|x-2|+|3-x|=a
$$

have exactly two solutions?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. For which real numbers $a$ does the equation

$$
|x-2|+|3-x|=a
$$

have exactly two solutions? -/
theorem algebra_242915 (a : ℝ) :
    {x | abs (x - 2) + abs (3 - x) = a}.encard = 2 ↔ a > 1 := by

informal_statement:
Suppose $x,y,,a,b,c,d,e,f$ are real numbers satifying 
i)$\max{(a,0)}+\max{(b,0)}<x+ay+bz<1+\min{(a,0)}+\min{(b,0)}$, and
ii)$\max{(c,0)}+\max{(d,0)}<cx+y+dz<1+\min{(c,0)}+\min{(d,0)}$, and
iii)$\max{(e,0)}+\max{(f,0)}<ex+fy+z<1+\min{(e,0)}+\min{(f,0)}$.
Prove that $0<x,y,z<1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose $x,y,,a,b,c,d,e,f$ are real numbers satifying 
i)$\max{(a,0)}+\max{(b,0)}<x+ay+bz<1+\min{(a,0)}+\min{(b,0)}$, and
ii)$\max{(c,0)}+\max{(d,0)}<cx+y+dz<1+\min{(c,0)}+\min{(d,0)}$, and
iii)$\max{(e,0)}+\max{(f,0)}<ex+fy+z<1+\min{(e,0)}+\min{(f,0)}$.
Prove that $0<x,y,z<1$. -/
theorem inequalities_91655 (x y z a b c d e f : ℝ)
    (h₁ : max a 0 + max b 0 < x + a * y + b * z ∧ x + a * y + b * z < 1 + min a 0 + min b 0)
    (h₂ : max c 0 + max d 0 < c * x + y + d * z ∧ c * x + y + d * z < 1 + min c 0 + min d 0)
    (h₃ : max e 0 + max f 0 < e * x + f * y + z ∧ e * x + f * y + z < 1 + min e 0 + min f 0) :
    0 < x ∧ x < 1 ∧ 0 < y ∧ y < 1 ∧ 0 < z ∧ z < 1 := by

soln_description:
We substitute the side condition for $\alpha$, multiply both sides by the common denominator $x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}>0$, and obtain the equivalent inequality

$$
\left(x^{2}+x y+x z+y z\right)\left(y^{2}+y x+y z+x z\right)\left(z^{2}+z x+z y+x y\right) \geq C x y^{2} z\left(x^{2}+z^{2}+2 x z\right) .
$$

The inequality is now homogeneous of degree 6, so the side condition is no longer relevant. Each of the factors can be factored:

$$
(x+y)(x+z)(y+x)(y+z)(z+x)(z+y) \geq C^{2} z(x+z)^{2} .
$$

We cancel $(x+z)^{2}>0$ and obtain the equivalent inequality

$$
(x+y)^{2}(z+y)^{2} \geq C x y^{2} z .
$$

If we estimate each of the two factors on the left using the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality, we obtain an optimal value of $C=16$, which is achieved for $x=y=z=\sqrt{\alpha / 3}$.

(Clemens Heuberger)
informal_statement:
Let $\alpha$ be a positive real number. Determine for this $\alpha$ the largest real number $C$ such that for all positive real numbers $x, y,$ and $z$ with $xy + yz + zx = \alpha$, the inequality

$$
\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{x^{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{y^{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{z^{2}}\right) \geq C \cdot\left(\frac{x}{z}+\frac{z}{x}+2\right)
$$

holds. When does equality hold?

(Walther Janous)
informal_proof:
We want to prove that `16` is the greatest constant `C` such that for all positive real numbers `x, y, z` satisfying `xy + yz + zx = α`, the inequality `(1 + α/x^2)(1 + α/y^2)(1 + α/z^2) ≥ C(x/z + z/x + 2)` holds. To prove that `16` is the greatest constant, we must show two things:
1.  `16` itself satisfies the inequality for all valid `x, y, z`.
2.  Any `C` that satisfies the inequality for all valid `x, y, z` must be less than or equal to `16`.

**Part 1: Showing that `16` is a valid constant.**
We need to demonstrate that for any `x, y, z > 0` and `α > 0` such that `xy + yz + zx = α`, the following inequality holds:
` (1 + α/x^2)(1 + α/y^2)(1 + α/z^2) ≥ 16(x/z + z/x + 2) `

Let `x, y, z` be positive real numbers (`hx, hy, hz`), and let `h` be the condition `xy + yz + zx = α`.
To prove the inequality, we will show that its left-hand side minus its right-hand side is non-negative.
` (1 + α/x^2)(1 + α/y^2)(1 + α/z^2) - 16(x/z + z/x + 2) ≥ 0 `

First, we express this difference as a single fraction. The common denominator will be `x^2 y^2 z^2`. Since `x, y, z > 0`, their squares are also positive, so the denominator `x^2 y^2 z^2` is strictly positive.
The expression transforms to:
` ((x^2 + α)(y^2 + α)(z^2 + α) - 16(x^3 y^2 z + x y^2 z^3 + 2 x^2 y^2 z^2)) / (x^2 y^2 z^2) `

For this fraction to be non-negative, we only need to show that its numerator is non-negative:
` (x^2 + α)(y^2 + α)(z^2 + α) - 16(x^3 y^2 z + x y^2 z^3 + 2 x^2 y^2 z^2) ≥ 0 `

Now, we substitute the condition `α = xy + yz + zx` into this numerator.
The resulting algebraic expression, after expanding and simplifying, is known to be non-negative. This is a non-trivial algebraic inequality which can be proven by expressing it as a sum of squares or using inequalities like AM-GM. In Lean, this complex algebraic verification is handled automatically by the `nlinarith` tactic, which utilizes given non-negativity facts (such as squares of real numbers being non-negative: e.g., `(x*y - y*z)^2 ≥ 0`, `(x - y)^2 ≥ 0`, etc., and the positivity of `x, y, z`). This confirms that the numerator is indeed non-negative.
Since the numerator is non-negative and the denominator `x^2 y^2 z^2` is positive, their ratio is non-negative. Thus, the original inequality holds for `C = 16`.

**Part 2: Showing that `16` is the greatest constant.**
Let `C` be any real number such that for all `x, y, z > 0` with `xy + yz + zx = α`, the inequality `(1 + α/x^2)(1 + α/y^2)(1 + α/z^2) ≥ C(x/z + z/x + 2)` holds. We need to show that `C ≤ 16`.

To do this, we choose specific values for `x, y, z` that satisfy the conditions and for which the inequality holds with equality when `C = 16`. This often happens when `x = y = z`.
Let's choose `x = y = z = \sqrt{\alpha/3}`.
1.  **Check positivity**: Since `α > 0`, we have `α/3 > 0`, and thus `\sqrt{\alpha/3} > 0`. So `x, y, z > 0`.
2.  **Check the side condition**:
    `xy + yz + zx = (\sqrt{\alpha/3})(\sqrt{\alpha/3}) + (\sqrt{\alpha/3})(\sqrt{\alpha/3}) + (\sqrt{\alpha/3})(\sqrt{\alpha/3})`
    `= \alpha/3 + \alpha/3 + \alpha/3 = \alpha`.
    The condition `xy + yz + zx = α` is satisfied.

Now, we substitute these specific values into the inequality `(1 + α/x^2)(1 + α/y^2)(1 + α/z^2) ≥ C(x/z + z/x + 2)`:

*   **Evaluate the Left-Hand Side (LHS)**:
    ` (1 + α/(\sqrt{\alpha/3})^2)(1 + α/(\sqrt{\alpha/3})^2)(1 + α/(\sqrt{\alpha/3})^2) `
    Since `(\sqrt{\alpha/3})^2 = \alpha/3` (because `α/3 > 0`), this simplifies to:
    ` (1 + α/(\alpha/3))(1 + α/(\alpha/3))(1 + α/(\alpha/3)) = (1 + 3)(1 + 3)(1 + 3) = 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4 = 64 `

*   **Evaluate the factor `(x/z + z/x + 2)` from the Right-Hand Side (RHS)**:
    ` (\sqrt{\alpha/3}/\sqrt{\alpha/3} + \sqrt{\alpha/3}/\sqrt{\alpha/3} + 2) `
    Since `\sqrt{\alpha/3} \neq 0`, `\sqrt{\alpha/3}/\sqrt{\alpha/3} = 1`.
    So, the factor simplifies to: ` 1 + 1 + 2 = 4 `

Substituting these evaluations back into the inequality for `C`, we get:
` 64 ≥ C \cdot 4 `

Dividing both sides by `4` (which is positive), we conclude:
` 16 ≥ C ` or ` C ≤ 16 `

Since `C` was an arbitrary constant satisfying the inequality, and we have shown `C ≤ 16`, it follows that `16` is the greatest such constant.

Combining both parts, `16` is indeed the greatest constant `C` satisfying the given condition.

The equality holds when `x = y = z = \sqrt{\alpha/3}`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $\alpha$ be a positive real number. Determine for this $\alpha$ the largest real number $C$ such that for all positive real numbers $x, y,$ and $z$ with $xy + yz + zx = \alpha$, the inequality

$$
\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{x^{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{y^{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{z^{2}}\right) \geq C \cdot\left(\frac{x}{z}+\frac{z}{x}+2\right)
$$

holds. When does equality hold?

(Walther Janous) -/
theorem inequalities_259818 (α : ℝ) (hα : α > 0) :
    IsGreatest {C | ∀ x y z : ℝ, x > 0 → y > 0 → z > 0 → x * y + y * z + z * x = α →
      (1 + α / x ^ 2) * (1 + α / y ^ 2) * (1 + α / z ^ 2) ≥ C * (x / z + z / x + 2)} 16 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem inequalities_259818 (α : ℝ) (hα : α > 0) :
    IsGreatest {C | ∀ x y z : ℝ, x > 0 → y > 0 → z > 0 → x * y + y * z + z * x = α →
      (1 + α / x ^ 2) * (1 + α / y ^ 2) * (1 + α / z ^ 2) ≥ C * (x / z + z / x + 2)} 16 := by
  constructor
  · -- Show that 16 is in the set.
    intro x y z hx hy hz h
    have h1 : (1 + α / x ^ 2) * (1 + α / y ^ 2) * (1 + α / z ^ 2) ≥ 16 * (x / z + z / x + 2) := by
      have h2 : 0 < x * y * z := by
        positivity
      have h3 : 0 < x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2 := by
        positivity
      have h4 : (1 + α / x ^ 2) * (1 + α / y ^ 2) * (1 + α / z ^ 2) - 16 * (x / z + z / x + 2) ≥ 0 := by
        have h5 : (1 + α / x ^ 2) * (1 + α / y ^ 2) * (1 + α / z ^ 2) - 16 * (x / z + z / x + 2) =
            ((x ^ 2 + α) * (y ^ 2 + α) * (z ^ 2 + α) - 16 * (x ^ 3 * y ^ 2 * z + x * y ^ 2 * z ^ 3 + 2 * x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2)) / (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2) := by
          field_simp
          ring
        rw [h5]
        have h7 : (x ^ 2 + α) * (y ^ 2 + α) * (z ^ 2 + α) ≥ 16 * (x ^ 3 * y ^ 2 * z + x * y ^ 2 * z ^ 3 + 2 * x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2) := by
          have h8 : α = x * y + y * z + z * x := by linarith
          rw [h8]
          nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * y - y * z), sq_nonneg (y * z - z * x), sq_nonneg (z * x - x * y),
            sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x),
            sq_nonneg (x * (x - y)), sq_nonneg (x * (x - z)), sq_nonneg (y * (y - z)), sq_nonneg (y * (y - x)), sq_nonneg (z * (z - x)), sq_nonneg (z * (z - y)),
            mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hy hz, mul_pos hz hx, mul_pos (mul_pos hx hy) hz
          ]
        have h6 : ((x ^ 2 + α) * (y ^ 2 + α) * (z ^ 2 + α) - 16 * (x ^ 3 * y ^ 2 * z + x * y ^ 2 * z ^ 3 + 2 * x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2)) ≥ 0 := by linarith
        have h7 : ((x ^ 2 + α) * (y ^ 2 + α) * (z ^ 2 + α) - 16 * (x ^ 3 * y ^ 2 * z + x * y ^ 2 * z ^ 3 + 2 * x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2)) / (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 * z ^ 2) ≥ 0 := by
          apply div_nonneg
          all_goals linarith
        linarith
      linarith
    linarith
  · -- Show that 16 is greatest
    intro C hC
    have h1 := hC (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) (by positivity) (by positivity) (by positivity) (by
      have h1 : Real.sqrt (α / 3) * Real.sqrt (α / 3) + Real.sqrt (α / 3) * Real.sqrt (α / 3) + Real.sqrt (α / 3) * Real.sqrt (α / 3) = α := by
        have h2 : Real.sqrt (α / 3) ^ 2 = α / 3 := by
          rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
          positivity
        linarith
      linarith
    )
    have h3 : (1 + α / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) ^ 2) * (1 + α / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) ^ 2) * (1 + α / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) ^ 2) = 64 := by
      have h4 : Real.sqrt (α / 3) ^ 2 = α / 3 := by
        rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
        positivity
      rw [h4]
      field_simp
      nlinarith
    have h4 : (Real.sqrt (α / 3) / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) + (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) + 2) = (4 : ℝ) := by
      have h11 : Real.sqrt (α / 3) / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) = 1 := by
        field_simp [show Real.sqrt (α / 3) ≠ 0 by positivity]
      linarith
    have h5 : (1 + α / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) ^ 2) * (1 + α / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) ^ 2) * (1 + α / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) ^ 2) ≥ C * (Real.sqrt (α / 3) / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) + (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) / (Real.sqrt (α / 3)) + 2) := by
      simpa using h1
    rw [h3, h4] at h5
    nlinarith

10.【Analysis and Solution】Let $\sqrt{k^{2}-p k}=n, n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$, then $k^{2}-p k-n^{2}=0, k=\frac{p \pm \sqrt{p^{2}+4 n^{2}}}{2}$, thus $p^{2}+$ $4 n^{2}$ is a perfect square, set it as $m^{2}, m \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$, then $(m-2 n)(m+2 n)=p^{2}$.
$\because p$ is a prime number, and $p \geqslant 3, \therefore\left\{\begin{array}{l}m-2 n=1 \\ m+2 n=p^{2}\end{array}\right.$, solving gives $\left\{\begin{array}{l}m=\frac{p^{2}+1}{2} \\ n=\frac{p^{2}-1}{4}\end{array}\right.$.
$\therefore k=\frac{p \pm m}{2}=\frac{2 p \pm\left(p^{2}+1\right)}{4}$, hence $k=\frac{(p+1)^{2}}{4}$. (negative value discarded)
informal_statement: 10. Let $p$ be a given odd prime, and let the positive integer $k$ be such that $\sqrt{k-p k}$ is also a positive integer, then $k=$
informal_proof:
Let $p$ be an odd prime number, and let $k$ be a natural number. We are given the hypothesis that there exists a positive natural number $m$ such that $m^2 = k - p \cdot k$. Our goal is to demonstrate that under these conditions, this hypothesis is actually self-contradictory, thus making the theorem statement vacuously true.

We proceed with the following steps:

1.  **Deconstruct the Hypothesis:** We start by unpacking the given hypothesis `hk`. This hypothesis states that there exists a natural number $m$ such that $0 < m$ and $m^2 = k - p \cdot k$. Let's denote these two facts as (H1) $0 < m$ and (H2) $m^2 = k - p \cdot k$.

2.  **Establish `p`'s Lower Bound:** Since $p$ is a prime number, by definition, $p \geq 2$. Furthermore, we are given that $p$ is odd. Combining these, we know that $p \geq 3$. For our immediate purposes, $p \geq 2$ is sufficient.

3.  **Relate `k` and `p \cdot k`:**
    *   Since $p$ is a prime number, $p \geq 2$. This implies $p \geq 1$.
    *   Since $k$ is a natural number, $k \geq 0$.
    *   For any natural numbers $a, b$ where $b \geq 1$, it holds that $a \leq a \cdot b$. Therefore, $k \leq k \cdot p$ (or $k \leq p \cdot k$). This is because $p \geq 1$, so multiplying $k$ by $p$ either keeps it the same (if $p=1$, which is not the case for prime $p$) or increases it (if $p > 1$).

4.  **Evaluate `k - p \cdot k` in Natural Number Arithmetic:**
    *   In the system of natural numbers ($\mathbb{N}$), the subtraction operation $a - b$ is typically defined as $\max(0, a - b)$.
    *   From the previous step, we established that $k \leq p \cdot k$.
    *   Therefore, when calculating $k - p \cdot k$ in $\mathbb{N}$, since $k \leq p \cdot k$, the result is $\max(0, k - p \cdot k) = 0$.
    *   Thus, we conclude that $k - p \cdot k = 0$.

5.  **Simplify (H2):** Now we use our finding from the previous step. We had the hypothesis (H2) $m^2 = k - p \cdot k$. Substituting $k - p \cdot k = 0$ into this equation, we get $m^2 = 0$.

6.  **Derive `m = 0`:** For any natural number $m$, if its square is zero ($m^2 = 0$), then $m$ itself must be zero. Hence, we have $m = 0$.

7.  **Contradiction:** We have now derived $m = 0$. However, our initial hypothesis (H1) states that $0 < m$, meaning $m$ is a positive natural number. The statement $0 < m$ and $m = 0$ are contradictory.

8.  **Conclusion:** Since we have derived a contradiction directly from the given hypotheses, the conjunction of the hypotheses must be false. In other words, the conditions stated in the problem (that $p$ is an odd prime, $k$ is a positive integer, AND $\sqrt{k - p \cdot k}$ is a positive integer) can never simultaneously be true. When the premise of an "if-then" statement is false, the entire implication is considered vacuously true. Therefore, the statement that $k = \frac{(p+1)^2}{4}$ holds true because its conditions are never met.

The proof is complete.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. Let $p$ be a given odd prime, and let the positive integer $k$ be such that $\sqrt{k-p k}$ is also a positive integer, then $k=$ -/
theorem number_theory_280761 (p : ℕ) (hp : Odd p ∧ Nat.Prime p)
    (k : ℕ) (hk : ∃ m : ℕ, 0 < m ∧ m^2 = k - p * k) :
    k = ((p + 1)^2) / 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_280761 (p : ℕ) (hp : Odd p ∧ Nat.Prime p)
    (k : ℕ) (hk : ∃ m : ℕ, 0 < m ∧ m^2 = k - p * k) :
    k = ((p + 1)^2) / 4 := by
  rcases hk with ⟨m, hm, heq⟩
  exfalso
  have heq1 : k ≤ p * k := by
    have hp12 : p ≥ 1 := by 
      have hp5 := hp.right
      have : p ≥ 2 := Nat.Prime.two_le hp5
      linarith
    nlinarith [show k ≥ 0 by omega, hp12]
  -- k - p * k = 0 because $k \cdot (1 - p)$ is negative
  have heq2 : k - p * k = 0 := by
    omega
  rw [heq2] at heq
  -- We established from above analysis that $k \geq 0$. Since $p \cdot k \geq k$
  -- which implies $0 \cdot m^2 = k - p \cdot k$, now $m > 0$ implies $0 > 0$.
  have eq1 : m ^ 2 = (0 : ℕ) := by 
    omega 
  have h3 : m = 0 := by
    nlinarith
  linarith

soln_description:
Let's try to apply the AM-GM inequality to the left member, which is composed of a sum of 2 terms:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(1+\frac{a}{b}\right)^{n}+\left(1+\frac{b}{a}\right)^{n} & \geq 2 \sqrt{\left(1+\frac{a}{b}\right)^{n} \times\left(1+\frac{b}{a}\right)^{n}} \\
& =2 \sqrt{\left[\left(1+\frac{a}{b}\right)\left(1+\frac{b}{a}\right)\right]^{n}} \\
& =2 \sqrt{\left(2+\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a}\right)^{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We then recall exercise 3: the sum of a number and its inverse is always greater than or equal to 2. Therefore, we have: $\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geq 2$, which finally leads to

$$
\left(1+\frac{a}{b}\right)^{n}+\left(1+\frac{b}{a}\right)^{n} \geq 2 \sqrt{(2+2)^{n}}=2^{n+1}
$$

Substituting into $a_{2}^{2}=a_{1} a_{3}$, we get $r=-1$.
Thus, $S_{n}=2^{n}-1$.
Then $a_{n}=2^{n-1}, b_{n}=2\left(1+\log _{2} a_{n}\right)=2 n$, $a_{n} b_{n}=n \times 2^{n}$.
Therefore, $T_{n}=1 \times 2^{1}+2 \times 2^{2}+\cdots+$
$$
\begin{array}{c}
(n-1) \times 2^{n-1}+n \times 2^{n} \\
\Rightarrow 2 T_{n}=1 \times 2^{2}+2 \times 2^{3}+\cdots+ \\

Subtracting the above two equations, we get

Thus, the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $\left\{a_{n} b_{n}\right\}$ is

import Mathlib

/- 13. Let $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ be a geometric sequence with the sum of the first $n$ terms $S_{n}=2^{n}+r$ (where $r$ is a constant). Let $b_{n}=2\left(1+\log _{2} a_{n}\right)\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$.
(1) Find the sum of the first $n$ terms $T_{n}$ of the sequence $\left\{a_{n} b_{n}\right\}$;
(2) If for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
\frac{1+b_{1}}{b_{1}} \cdot \frac{1+b_{2}}{b_{2}} \cdots \cdots \frac{1+b_{n}}{b_{n}} \geqslant k \sqrt{n+1} \text {, }
$$

find the maximum value of the real number $k$. -/
theorem algebra_178919 {a b : ℕ → ℝ} {r : ℝ} (ha : ∃ d, ∀ n, a n = a 0 * d ^ n)
    (hsum : ∀ n, ∑ i in Finset.range n, a i = 2 ^ n + r)
    (hb : ∀ n, b n = 2 * (1 + Real.logb 2 (a n))) :
    (∀ n, ∑ i in Finset.range n, a i * b i = 3 * Real.sqrt 2 / 4 * Real.sqrt (n + 1)) ∧
    (∀ k, (∀ n, ∏ i in Finset.range n, (1 + b i) / b i ≥ k * Real.sqrt (n + 1)) →
      k ≤ 3 * Real.sqrt 2 / 4) := by

8. Let $a=(1-y, x+y-3,-2 x-y+6), b=(1,2,1)$, then $a \cdot b=(1-y) \cdot 1+2 \cdot(x+y-3)+$ $(-2 x-y+6) \cdot 1=1$,
$$
|a| \cdot|b|=\sqrt{(1-y)^{2}+(x+y-3)^{2}+(-2 x-y+6)^{2}} \cdot \sqrt{1^{2}+2^{2}+1^{2}}=\sqrt{f(x, y)} \cdot \sqrt{6} \text {. }
$$

And $a \cdot b \leqslant|a| \cdot|b|$,
then $1 \leqslant \sqrt{f(x \cdot y)} \cdot \sqrt{6}$,

which means $f(x \cdot y) \geqslant \frac{1}{6}$. Equality holds if and only if $a=\lambda b(\lambda>0)$.
Thus, by $\frac{1-y}{1}=\frac{x+y-3}{2}=\frac{-2 x-y+6}{1}=\lambda>0$,

we get $x=\frac{5}{2}, y=\frac{5}{6}, \lambda=\frac{1}{6}$, i.e., when $x=\frac{5}{2}, y=\frac{5}{6}$, $f(x, y)_{\min }=\frac{1}{6}$.
informal_statement: 8. (2001 National Junior High School League Question) Find the values of real numbers $x$ and $y$ that minimize the function $f(x, y)=(1-y)^{2}+(x+y-$ $3)^{2}+(2 x+y-6)^{2}$.
informal_proof:
We want to prove that the least value of the function $f(x, y)=(1-y)^{2}+(x+y-3)^{2}+(2 x+y-6)^{2}$ is $1/6$. This involves two main steps: first, demonstrating that $1/6$ is a possible value of the function (i.e., it is in the set of its images); and second, showing that no value of the function can be less than $1/6$.

**Part 1: Showing that $1/6$ is a value the function can attain.**

We need to find specific real numbers $x$ and $y$ such that $f(x, y) = 1/6$.
Let's choose $x = 5/2$ and $y = 5/6$. Substituting these values into the function:
\begin{align*} f(5/2, 5/6) &= (1 - 5/6)^2 + (5/2 + 5/6 - 3)^2 + (2 \cdot 5/2 + 5/6 - 6)^2 \\ &= (1/6)^2 + (15/6 + 5/6 - 18/6)^2 + (5 + 5/6 - 6)^2 \\ &= (1/6)^2 + (2/6)^2 + (-1 + 5/6)^2 \\ &= (1/6)^2 + (1/3)^2 + (-1/6)^2 \\ &= 1/36 + 1/9 + 1/36 \\ &= 1/36 + 4/36 + 1/36 \\ &= 6/36 \\ &= 1/6 \end{align*}
Thus, we have found specific values $x = 5/2$ and $y = 5/6$ for which the function $f(x, y)$ evaluates to $1/6$. This confirms that $1/6$ is indeed an element of the set of values taken by the function.

**Part 2: Showing that $1/6$ is a lower bound for all function values.**

Let $f$ be any value in the set, meaning there exist real numbers $x$ and $y$ such that $f = (1-y)^{2}+(x+y-3)^{2}+(2 x+y-6)^{2}$. We need to show that $f \ge 1/6$.
Let $X = x - 5/2$ and $Y = y - 5/6$. These represent the deviations of $x$ and $y$ from the specific values found in Part 1. We can express $x = X + 5/2$ and $y = Y + 5/6$.

Now, let's rewrite the terms in $f(x,y)$ using $X$ and $Y$:
\begin{align*} 1 - y &= 1 - (Y + 5/6) = 1/6 - Y \\ x + y - 3 &= (X + 5/2) + (Y + 5/6) - 3 = X + Y + (15/6 + 5/6 - 18/6) = X + Y + 2/6 = X + Y + 1/3 \\ 2x + y - 6 &= 2(X + 5/2) + (Y + 5/6) - 6 = 2X + 5 + Y + 5/6 - 6 = 2X + Y + (30/6 + 5/6 - 36/6) = 2X + Y - 1/6 \end{align*}
Substituting these into the expression for $f(x,y)$:
\begin{align*} f(x,y) &= (1/6 - Y)^2 + (X + Y + 1/3)^2 + (2X + Y - 1/6)^2 \\ &= ( (1/6)^2 - 2(1/6)Y + Y^2 ) + ( X^2 + Y^2 + (1/3)^2 + 2XY + 2(1/3)X + 2(1/3)Y ) \\ & \quad + ( (2X)^2 + Y^2 + (-1/6)^2 + 2(2X)Y + 2(2X)(-1/6) + 2Y(-1/6) ) \\ &= (1/36 - 1/3 Y + Y^2) + (X^2 + Y^2 + 1/9 + 2XY + 2/3 X + 2/3 Y) \\ & \quad + (4X^2 + Y^2 + 1/36 + 4XY - 2/3 X - 1/3 Y) \end{align*}
Now, collect terms:
\begin{align*} f(x,y) &= (1/36 + 1/9 + 1/36) & \quad \text{(constant terms)} \\ & \quad + (-1/3 Y + 2/3 Y - 1/3 Y) & \quad \text{(terms in Y)} \\ & \quad + (2/3 X - 2/3 X) & \quad \text{(terms in X)} \\ & \quad + (Y^2 + Y^2 + Y^2) & \quad \text{(terms in } Y^2) \\ & \quad + (X^2 + 4X^2) & \quad \text{(terms in } X^2) \\ & \quad + (2XY + 4XY) & \quad \text{(terms in } XY) \\ &= (6/36) + (0) + (0) + (3Y^2) + (5X^2) + (6XY) \\ &= 1/6 + 5X^2 + 6XY + 3Y^2 \end{align*}
To show that $f(x,y) \geq 1/6$, we need to prove that $5X^2 + 6XY + 3Y^2 \geq 0$. We can do this by completing the square for this quadratic expression:
\begin{align*} 5X^2 + 6XY + 3Y^2 &= 5(X^2 + \frac{6}{5}XY + \frac{3}{5}Y^2) \\ &= 5\left( \left(X + \frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 - \left(\frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 + \frac{3}{5}Y^2 \right) \\ &= 5\left( \left(X + \frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 - \frac{9}{25}Y^2 + \frac{15}{25}Y^2 \right) \\ &= 5\left( \left(X + \frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 + \frac{6}{25}Y^2 \right) \\ &= 5\left(X + \frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 + \frac{6}{5}Y^2 \end{align*}
Since $X$ and $Y$ are real numbers, their squares $(X + \frac{3}{5}Y)^2$ and $Y^2$ are non-negative. Also, $5$ and $6/5$ are positive coefficients. Therefore, the entire expression $5\left(X + \frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 + \frac{6}{5}Y^2$ must be non-negative.

Combining this with our previous result:
$f(x,y) = 1/6 + \left( 5\left(X + \frac{3}{5}Y\right)^2 + \frac{6}{5}Y^2 \right)$.
Since the term in parentheses is non-negative, it follows that $f(x,y) \geq 1/6$.

Therefore, for any real numbers $x$ and $y$, $f(x,y) \geq 1/6$.

**Conclusion:**

We have shown that $1/6$ is a value that the function $f(x,y)$ can attain (specifically at $x=5/2, y=5/6$), and that $1/6$ is a lower bound for all possible values of $f(x,y)$. By the definition of the least element, $1/6$ is the minimum value of the function $f(x,y)$.

The final answer is $\boxed{1/6}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 8. (2001 National Junior High School League Question) Find the values of real numbers $x$ and $y$ that minimize the function $f(x, y)=(1-y)^{2}+(x+y-$ $3)^{2}+(2 x+y-6)^{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_277761 :
  IsLeast {f | ∃ x y : ℝ, f = (1 - y)^2 + (x + y - 3)^2 + (2 * x + y - 6)^2} (1 / 6) :=
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem algebra_277761 :
  IsLeast {f | ∃ x y : ℝ, f = (1 - y)^2 + (x + y - 3)^2 + (2 * x + y - 6)^2} (1 / 6) := by
  constructor
  · -- Show 1/6 is in the set
    use 5 / 2, 5 / 6 
    norm_num 
  · -- Show 1/6 is the least value in the set
    intro f hf 
    rcases hf with ⟨x, y, h⟩ 
    rw [h]
    have h1 : (1 - y)^2 + (x + y - 3)^2 + (2 * x + y - 6)^2 ≥ 1 / 6 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 5 / 2), sq_nonneg (y - 5 / 6), 
          sq_nonneg ( (1 - y) - (1/6) ), sq_nonneg ( (x + y - 3) - (1/3) ), 
          sq_nonneg ( (2 * x + y - 6) - (-1/6) ), sq_nonneg (x - 5 / 2), sq_nonneg (y - 5 / 6)]
    linarith

informal_statement: $1\times2\times3\times4\times \cdots \times2018$ can be divided by $175^n$, where $n$ is an integer, find the maximum possible value of $n$.
informal_proof:
We aim to prove that 251 is the maximum possible integer $n$ such that $175^n$ divides the product $\prod_{i=1}^{2018} (i+1)$, which is equivalent to $175^n \mid 2018!$. To achieve this, we will demonstrate that 251 is the greatest element of the set $S = \{n \in \mathbb{Z} \mid 175^n \text{ divides } 2018!\}$. This requires proving two conditions:
1.  251 is an element of the set $S$.
2.  For any $n$ in the set $S$, $n$ must be less than or equal to 251.

**Part 1: Showing that 251 is an element of $S$**
To show that $251 \in S$, we need to prove that $175^{251}$ divides $2018!$.
First, we find the prime factorization of the base $175$:
$175 = 5^2 \cdot 7$.
Therefore, $175^{251} = (5^2 \cdot 7)^{251} = 5^{2 \cdot 251} \cdot 7^{251} = 5^{502} \cdot 7^{251}$.

Next, we determine the highest power of 5 and 7 that divides $2018!$. We use Legendre's Formula, which states that the exponent of a prime $p$ in $k!$ is given by $\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \lfloor k/p^j \rfloor$.

*   **Exponent of 5 in $2018!$:**
    *   $\lfloor 2018/5 \rfloor = 403$
    *   $\lfloor 2018/25 \rfloor = 80$
    *   $\lfloor 2018/125 \rfloor = 16$
    *   $\lfloor 2018/625 \rfloor = 3$
    *   The sum of these is $403 + 80 + 16 + 3 = 502$.
    So, $5^{502}$ is the highest power of 5 that divides $2018!$. For $175^{251}$ to divide $2018!$, the exponent of 5, which is $502$, must be less than or equal to $502$, which is true.

*   **Exponent of 7 in $2018!$:**
    *   $\lfloor 2018/7 \rfloor = 288$
    *   $\lfloor 2018/49 \rfloor = 41$
    *   $\lfloor 2018/343 \rfloor = 5$
    *   The sum of these is $288 + 41 + 5 = 334$.
    So, $7^{334}$ is the highest power of 7 that divides $2018!$. For $175^{251}$ to divide $2018!$, the exponent of 7, which is $251$, must be less than or equal to $334$, which is true.

Since both $5^{502}$ divides $2018!$ and $7^{251}$ divides $2018!$, and 5 and 7 are distinct primes, their product $5^{502} \cdot 7^{251} = 175^{251}$ also divides $2018!$. This confirms that $251 \in S$.

**Part 2: Showing that for any $n \in S$, $n \le 251$**
We prove this by contradiction.
Let $n$ be an integer such that $175^n$ divides $2018!$. This is our hypothesis.
Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $n$ is *not* less than or equal to $251$. This means $n > 251$.
Since $n$ is an integer, $n > 251$ implies $n \ge 252$.

Now we will derive a contradiction by showing that two opposing statements are true:
1.  **Statement A: $175^{252}$ does not divide $2018!$.**
    From our prime factorization in Part 1, the exponent of 5 in $2018!$ is $502$.
    For $175^{252} = 5^{2 \cdot 252} \cdot 7^{252} = 5^{504} \cdot 7^{252}$ to divide $2018!$, the exponent of 5 in $175^{252}$ (which is 504) must be less than or equal to the exponent of 5 in $2018!$ (which is 502). However, $504 \not\le 502$. Therefore, $5^{504}$ does not divide $2018!$, which implies that $175^{252}$ does not divide $2018!$.

2.  **Statement B: $175^{252}$ divides $2018!$.**
    We are given that $175^n$ divides $2018!$.
    We deduced from our assumption ($n > 251$) that $n \ge 252$.
    Since $252 \le n$, it follows that $175^{252}$ divides $175^n$ (a smaller positive integer power always divides a larger or equal power of the same base).
    By the transitivity property of divisibility, if $175^{252}$ divides $175^n$, and $175^n$ divides $2018!$, then it must be that $175^{252}$ divides $2018!$.

We have now established both Statement A ($175^{252}$ does not divide $2018!$) and Statement B ($175^{252}$ divides $2018!$). These two statements are contradictory.
This contradiction arose from our initial assumption that $n > 251$. Therefore, our assumption must be false. Hence, for any $n$ such that $175^n$ divides $2018!$, we must have $n \le 251$.

**Conclusion**
We have shown that $251$ is an element of $S$, and that any element $n \in S$ must satisfy $n \le 251$. Therefore, 251 is the greatest element of $S$. The maximum possible value of $n$ is 251.
$\square$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- $1\times2\times3\times4\times \cdots \times2018$ can be divided by $175^n$, where $n$ is an integer, find the maximum possible value of $n$.
 -/
theorem number_theory_4757 : IsGreatest {n | 175^n ∣ ∏ i ∈ range 2018, (i + 1)} 251 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Finset

theorem number_theory_4757 : IsGreatest {n | 175^n ∣ ∏ i ∈ range 2018, (i + 1)} 251 := by
  constructor
  · -- Show 251 is in the set
    native_decide
  · -- Show there is no greater n in the set
    intro n hn
    have h1 : 175 ^ n ∣ ∏ i ∈ range 2018, (i + 1) := hn
    by_contra h2
    push_neg at h2
    have h2' : n ≥ 252 := by
      omega
    have h3 : ¬ (175 ^ 252 ∣ ∏ i ∈ range 2018, (i + 1)) := by
      native_decide
    have h5 : 175 ^ 252 ∣ ∏ i ∈ range 2018, (i + 1) := by
      have h6 : 175 ^ n ∣ ∏ i ∈ range 2018, (i + 1) := h1
      have h7 : 175 ^ 252 ∣ 175 ^ n := by
        apply pow_dvd_pow _ (by omega)
      exact dvd_trans h7 h6
    have h4 : n ≥ 252 := h2'
    exact h3 h5

soln_description:
Solution:

$f(x)=2 \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4} \sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2)-\frac{5 \pi}{2}\right)=-2 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} \sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2)\right)$ Since $\sqrt{x-2}+x+2 \in[4 ; \infty)$, then $\sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2) \in[-1 ; 1], \quad \frac{\pi}{4} \sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2) \in[-\pi / 4 ; \pi / 4]$.

Therefore, $\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} \sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2)\right) \in[\sqrt{2} / 2 ; 1] \Rightarrow-2 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} \sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2)\right) \in[-2 ;-\sqrt{2}]$.

Answer: $[-2 ;-\sqrt{2}]$.

formal_statement:

/- 6. Find the set of values of the function $f(x)=2 \sin ((\pi / 4) \sin (\sqrt{x-2}+x+2)-(5 \pi / 2))$. -/
theorem algebra_262565 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : f = λ x => 2 * sin ((π / 4) * sin (sqrt (x - 2) + x + 2) - (5 * π / 2))) :
  range f = {y | -2 ≤ y ∧ y ≤ -sqrt 2} :=

soln_description:
Solution. The given equation is linear if we consider $x$ as a function of $y$:

$$
\frac{d x}{d y}-x \cos y=\sin 2 y
$$

We apply the method of variation of arbitrary constants. First, we solve the corresponding homogeneous equation

$$
\frac{d x}{d y}-x \cos y=0
$$

which is a separable variable equation. Its general solution is

$$
x=C e^{\sin y}, \quad C=\text { const. }
$$

We seek the general solution of equation (4) in the form

$$
x=C(y) e^{\sin y}
$$

where $C(y)$ is an unknown function of $y$. Substituting (5) into (4), we get

$$
C^{\prime}(y) e^{\sin y}+C(y) e^{\sin y} \cos y-C(y) e^{\sin y} \cos y=\sin 2 y
$$

or

$$
C^{\prime}(y)=e^{-\sin y} \sin 2 y
$$

From this, integrating by parts, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C(y)=\int e^{-\sin y} \sin 2 y d y=2 \int e^{-\sin y} \cos y \sin y d y= \\
& =2 \int \sin y d\left(-e^{-\sin y}\right)=2\left(-\sin y e^{-\sin y}+\int e^{-\sin y} \cos y d y\right)= \\
& =2\left(-\sin y e^{-\sin y}-e^{-\sin y}\right)+C
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
C(y)=-2 e^{-\sin y}(1+\sin y)+C .
$$

Substituting (6) into (5), we obtain the general solution of equation (4), and hence of the given equation:

$$
x=C e^{\sin y}-2(1+\sin y) . \quad \Delta
$$

Equation (1) can also be integrated as follows. We assume

$$
y=u(x) v(x)
$$

where $u(x)$ and $v(x)$ are unknown functions of $x$, one of which, for example $v(x)$, can be chosen arbitrarily. Substituting (7) into (1), after transformation we get

$$
v u^{\prime}+\left(p v+v^{\prime}\right) u=q(x) .
$$

Defining $v(x)$ from the condition $v^{\prime}+p v=0$, we then find from (8) the function $u(x)$, and consequently, the solution $y=u v$ of equation (1). As $v(x)$, we can take any particular solution of the equation $v^{\prime}+p v=0, v \not \equiv$.

  ∃ c, ∀ x, c * exp (sin (y x)) - 2 * (1 + sin (y x)) = 0 :=

formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Example 9 (1999 National High School League Question) Given $\theta=\arctan \frac{5}{12}$, then the principal value of the argument of the complex number $z=\frac{\cos 2 \theta+\mathrm{i} \sin 2 \theta}{239+\mathrm{i}}$ is -/
theorem algebra_288223 (θ : ℝ) (hθ : θ = Real.arctan (5 / 12)) :
    (cos (2 * θ) + I * sin (2 * θ)) / (239 + I) = (cos (π / 4) + I * sin (π / 4)) := by

soln_description:
1. **Claim**: The positive integer \( n \) has the property that there are only a finite number of positive multiples of \( n \) that have exactly \( n \) positive divisors if and only if \( n \) is squarefree or \( n = 4 \).

2. **Prime Factorization**: Let \( n = p_1^{e_1} p_2^{e_2} \cdots p_k^{e_k} \) be the prime factorization of \( n \).

3. **Case 1: \( n \) is not squarefree**:
    - If \( e_i \ge 2 \) for some odd prime \( p_i \), then \( p_i^{e_i-1} \ge e_i + 1 \) (since \( p_i \ge 3 \)).
    - For the other primes \( p_j \), \( p_j^{e_j} \ge e_j + 1 \).
    - Consider the number \( p_i^{p_i^{e_i-1}-1} \cdot \prod_{j \ne i} p_j^{p_j^{e_j}-1} \cdot q^{p_i-1} \), where \( q \) is an arbitrary prime different from \( p_i \).
    - This number has \( n \) divisors and is a multiple of \( n \), implying there are infinitely many such multiples.

4. **Case 2: \( p_1 = 2 \) and \( e_1 \ge 3 \)**:
    - Here, \( 2^{e_1-1} \ge e_1 + 1 \).
    - Using the same argument as above, we can construct infinitely many multiples of \( n \) with exactly \( n \) divisors.

5. **Case 3: \( n = 4p_1p_2 \cdots p_k \) for \( k \ge 1 \)**:
    - Consider the number \( 2^{p_1-1} p_1 p_2^{p_2-1} \cdots p_k^{p_k-1} q \), where \( q \) is a prime different from \( p_i \).
    - This number has \( n \) divisors and is a multiple of \( n \), implying there are infinitely many such multiples.

6. **Case 4: \( n \) is squarefree**:
    - Suppose \( n \) is squarefree with \( k \) prime divisors.
    - Any number with \( n \) divisors can have at most \( k \) distinct prime divisors since each prime contributes at least one factor to the number of divisors.
    - These primes must be the primes dividing \( n \), and there are only finitely many such combinations.

7. **Special Case: \( n = 4 \)**:
    - The result for \( n = 4 \) is trivial because the only multiples of 4 with exactly 4 divisors are of the form \( 2^2 \cdot p \), where \( p \) is a prime.

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{n \text{ is squarefree or } n = 4}
\]
informal_statement: Find all positive integers $n$ with the following property: There are only a finite number of positive multiples of $n$ that have exactly $n$ positive divisors.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all positive integers $n$ with the following property: There are only a finite number of positive multiples of $n$ that have exactly $n$ positive divisors. -/
theorem number_theory_32925 (n : ℕ) :
    n > 0 ∧ {m | m > 0 ∧ n ∣ m ∧ m.divisors.card = n}.Finite ↔
    Squarefree n ∨ n = 4 := by

informal_statement: In how many ways can the fraction $\frac{2}{15}$ be expressed as the sum of two unit fractions $\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive integers and $a \le b$?
informal_proof:
To find the number of ways the fraction $\frac{2}{15}$ can be expressed as the sum of two unit fractions $\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}$, with $a, b$ positive integers and $a \le b$, we first identify the set of all such pairs $(a, b)$ and then count its elements.

**Part 1: Identifying the Set of Solutions**

Let $S$ be the set of pairs $(a, b) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}$ satisfying the given conditions:
1.  $a > 0$
2.  $b > 0$
3.  $\frac{2}{15} = \frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}$
4.  $a \le b$

We aim to show that $S = \{(8, 120), (9, 45), (10, 30), (12, 20), (15, 15)\}$. We prove this by showing two inclusions: $S \subseteq \{(8, 120), \ldots, (15, 15)\}$ and $\{(8, 120), \ldots, (15, 15)\} \subseteq S$.

**1.1. If $(a, b)$ is a solution, then it must be one of the listed pairs.**

Assume $(a, b)$ satisfies conditions 1-4.
From condition 3, $\frac{2}{15} = \frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}$. We can rewrite the right side by finding a common denominator:
$\frac{2}{15} = \frac{b+a}{ab}$

Multiplying both sides by $15ab$ (which is non-zero since $a,b > 0$), we get an equivalent integer equation:
$2ab = 15(a+b)$

Now, we use this equation along with $a, b > 0$ and $a \le b$ to derive bounds for $a$ and $b$, and then systematically find all solutions.

*   **Deriving an upper bound for $a$:**
    Suppose, for contradiction, that $a > 120$.
    From $2ab = 15(a+b)$, we can rearrange to solve for $b$:
    $2ab - 15b = 15a$
    $b(2a - 15) = 15a$
    $b = \frac{15a}{2a - 15}$
    Since $a > 120$, we have $2a - 15 > 2(120) - 15 = 240 - 15 = 225$.
    Also, for $a > 120$, $2a - 15 > 2a/2 = a$. Thus, $b = \frac{15a}{2a-15} < \frac{15a}{2a} = \frac{15}{2} = 7.5$.
    Since $b$ is a natural number, this implies $b \le 7$.
    However, we are given $a \le b$. If $a > 120$ and $b \le 7$, this contradicts $a \le b$.
    Therefore, our assumption that $a > 120$ must be false. So, $a \le 120$.

*   **Deriving an upper bound for $b$:**
    Suppose, for contradiction, that $b > 120$.
    From $2ab = 15(a+b)$, we can rearrange to solve for $a$:
    $2ab - 15a = 15b$
    $a(2b - 15) = 15b$
    $a = \frac{15b}{2b - 15}$
    Since $b > 120$, we have $2b - 15 > 2(120) - 15 = 225$.
    Thus, $a = \frac{15b}{2b-15} < \frac{15b}{2b} = \frac{15}{2} = 7.5$.
    Since $a$ is a natural number, this implies $a \le 7$.
    Now we have $1 \le a \le 7$ and $b > 120$.
    Substitute these bounds into the equation $2ab = 15(a+b)$:
    $2ab = 15a + 15b$
    Since $a \le 7$, $15a \le 15 \times 7 = 105$.
    Since $b > 120$, $15b > 15 \times 120 = 1800$.
    So $15a + 15b > 1800$.
    However, $2ab \le 2 \times 7 \times b = 14b$.
    This would imply $14b > 1800$, so $b > \frac{1800}{14} \approx 128.57$.
    More precisely, we need to check if $a \le 7$ and $b > 120$ satisfy $a(2b-15) = 15b$.
    If $a=1$, $2b-15=15b \implies 13b=-15$, no positive solution.
    If $a=2$, $2(2b-15)=15b \implies 4b-30=15b \implies 11b=-30$, no positive solution.
    ...
    If $a=7$, $7(2b-15)=15b \implies 14b-105=15b \implies b=-105$, no positive solution.
    In all cases for $a \in \{1, \ldots, 7\}$, we find no positive $b$ satisfying the equation (or $b$ is not greater than 120 when it is positive).
    Therefore, our assumption that $b > 120$ must be false. So, $b \le 120$.

*   **Systematic Search:**
    We have established that $1 \le a \le b \le 120$ and $2ab = 15(a+b)$.
    We can rewrite the equation as $4ab - 30a - 30b = 0$.
    Adding $225$ to both sides, we can factor it (Simon's Favorite Factoring Trick):
    $4ab - 30a - 30b + 225 = 225$
    $(2a - 15)(2b - 15) = 225$
    Let $X = 2a - 15$ and $Y = 2b - 15$. Then $XY = 225$.
    Since $a, b > 0$, we have $2a \ge 2$ and $2b \ge 2$. So $X \ge -13$ and $Y \ge -13$.
    Since $a \le b$, it implies $2a - 15 \le 2b - 15$, so $X \le Y$.
    Since $X$ and $Y$ multiply to $225$ (a positive number), $X$ and $Y$ must have the same sign.
    If $X, Y$ were both negative, say $X=-k_1, Y=-k_2$ for positive $k_1, k_2$, then $k_1k_2=225$.
    $2a-15 = -k_1 \implies 2a = 15-k_1$. For $a>0$, $k_1 < 15$.
    $2b-15 = -k_2 \implies 2b = 15-k_2$. For $b>0$, $k_2 < 15$.
    So $k_1, k_2$ must be positive integers less than 15. The only factor pair of 225 that has both factors less than 15 is (1, 225), (3, 75), (5, 45), (9, 25). None of these fit the $k_1, k_2 < 15$ constraint. So $X$ and $Y$ must be positive.
    Thus, $X$ and $Y$ are positive integer factors of 225, with $X \le Y$.
    The factors of $225 = 3^2 \cdot 5^2$ are $1, 3, 5, 9, 15, 25, 45, 75, 225$.
    We list the pairs $(X, Y)$ such that $XY=225$ and $X \le Y$:
    *   $(1, 225) \implies 2a-15=1 \implies 2a=16 \implies a=8$.
        $2b-15=225 \implies 2b=240 \implies b=120$. Pair: $(8, 120)$.
    *   $(3, 75) \implies 2a-15=3 \implies 2a=18 \implies a=9$.
        $2b-15=75 \implies 2b=90 \implies b=45$. Pair: $(9, 45)$.
    *   $(5, 45) \implies 2a-15=5 \implies 2a=20 \implies a=10$.
        $2b-15=45 \implies 2b=60 \implies b=30$. Pair: $(10, 30)$.
    *   $(9, 25) \implies 2a-15=9 \implies 2a=24 \implies a=12$.
        $2b-15=25 \implies 2b=40 \implies b=20$. Pair: $(12, 20)$.
    *   $(15, 15) \implies 2a-15=15 \implies 2a=30 \implies a=15$.
        $2b-15=15 \implies 2b=30 \implies b=15$. Pair: $(15, 15)$.
    These are precisely the five pairs given. Thus, any solution $(a, b)$ must be one of these.

**1.2. Each listed pair is a solution.**

We verify each pair:

*   **For (8, 120):**
    *   $a=8 > 0$, $b=120 > 0$. (True)
    *   $a=8 \le b=120$. (True)
    *   $\frac{1}{8} + \frac{1}{120} = \frac{15}{120} + \frac{1}{120} = \frac{16}{120} = \frac{2 \times 8}{15 \times 8} = \frac{2}{15}$. (True)
*   **For (9, 45):**
    *   $a=9 > 0$, $b=45 > 0$. (True)
    *   $a=9 \le b=45$. (True)
    *   $\frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{45} = \frac{5}{45} + \frac{1}{45} = \frac{6}{45} = \frac{2 \times 3}{15 \times 3} = \frac{2}{15}$. (True)
*   **For (10, 30):**
    *   $a=10 > 0$, $b=30 > 0$. (True)
    *   $a=10 \le b=30$. (True)
    *   $\frac{1}{10} + \frac{1}{30} = \frac{3}{30} + \frac{1}{30} = \frac{4}{30} = \frac{2 \times 2}{15 \times 2} = \frac{2}{15}$. (True)
*   **For (12, 20):**
    *   $a=12 > 0$, $b=20 > 0$. (True)
    *   $a=12 \le b=20$. (True)
    *   $\frac{1}{12} + \frac{1}{20} = \frac{5}{60} + \frac{3}{60} = \frac{8}{60} = \frac{2 \times 4}{15 \times 4} = \frac{2}{15}$. (True)
*   **For (15, 15):**
    *   $a=15 > 0$, $b=15 > 0$. (True)
    *   $a=15 \le b=15$. (True)
    *   $\frac{1}{15} + \frac{1}{15} = \frac{2}{15}$. (True)

Since each of the five listed pairs satisfies all the conditions, and we have shown that any pair satisfying the conditions must be one of these five, the set of all solutions is exactly $\{(8, 120), (9, 45), (10, 30), (12, 20), (15, 15)\}$.

**Part 2: Calculating the Cardinality**

The set of solutions is $S = \{(8, 120), (9, 45), (10, 30), (12, 20), (15, 15)\}$.
This set contains 5 distinct elements.
Therefore, the cardinality of this set is 5.

The final answer is $\boxed{5}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In how many ways can the fraction $\frac{2}{15}$ be expressed as the sum of two unit fractions $\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive integers and $a \le b$? -/
theorem number_theory_4669 :
    {(a, b) : ℕ × ℕ | a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ (2 / 15 : ℚ) = 1 / a + 1 / b ∧ a ≤ b}.ncard = 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_4669 :
    {(a, b) : ℕ × ℕ | a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ (2 / 15 : ℚ) = 1 / a + 1 / b ∧ a ≤ b}.ncard = 5 := by
  have h1 : {(a, b) : ℕ × ℕ | a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ (2 / 15 : ℚ) = 1 / a + 1 / b ∧ a ≤ b} = {(8, 120), (9, 45), (10, 30), (12, 20), (15, 15)} := by
    ext ⟨a, b⟩
    simp
    constructor
    · -- Assume (a, b) satisfies the conditions
      rintro ⟨ha, hb, heq, hab⟩
      have h2 : (a : ℚ) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast ha
      have h3 : (b : ℚ) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast hb
      have h_eq : (2 : ℚ) * (a : ℚ) * (b : ℚ) = 15 * ((a : ℚ) + (b : ℚ)) := by
        field_simp at heq ⊢
        nlinarith
      have h_eq_nat : 2 * a * b = 15 * (a + b) := by
        exact_mod_cast h_eq
      have h3 : a ≤ b := hab
      have h4 : a ≤ 120 := by
        by_contra h
        push_neg at h
        have h5 : b < 8 := by
          nlinarith [show 2 * a * b = 15 * (a + b) from h_eq_nat]
        interval_cases b <;> nlinarith
      have h5 : b ≤ 120 := by
        by_contra h
        push_neg at h
        have h6 : a < 8 := by
          nlinarith [show 2 * a * b = 15 * (a + b) from h_eq_nat]
        interval_cases a <;> nlinarith
      interval_cases a <;> omega
    · -- Show that each pair in the finite set satisfies the conditions.
      rintro (⟨rfl, rfl⟩ | ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ | ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ | ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ | ⟨rfl, rfl⟩)
      · -- Check (8, 120)
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
      · -- Check (9, 45)
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
      · -- Check (10, 30)
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
      · -- Check (12, 20)
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
      · -- Check (15, 15)
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.ncard_eq_toFinset_card']
  simp [Set.toFinset]
  <;> try { native_decide }

informal_statement: The longest side of a right triangle is 5 meters and the shortest side is 3 meters. What is the area of the triangle in square meters?
informal_proof:
Let the side lengths of the right triangle be denoted by \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\). We are given the following conditions:
1.  All side lengths are positive: \(a > 0\), \(b > 0\), \(c > 0\).
2.  The Pythagorean theorem holds: \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\). This indicates it's a right triangle, where \(c\) is the hypotenuse.
3.  The hypotenuse has length 5: \(c = 5\).
4.  The shortest side of the triangle has length 3: \(\min(\min(a, b), c) = 3\). Note that \(\min(a, b)\) represents the shorter of the two legs, and \(\min(\min(a, b), c)\) represents the absolute shortest side among all three sides.

Our goal is to prove that the area of the triangle, given by \((1/2) \cdot a \cdot b\), is equal to 6.

First, we use the fact that \(c = 5\) to simplify condition (4). Substituting \(c=5\) into \(\min(\min(a, b), c) = 3\), we obtain:
\(\min(\min(a, b), 5) = 3\). (Let's call this equation (A)).

Next, we need to determine the value of \(\min(a, b)\). We consider two possibilities:

**Case 1: \(\min(a, b) \leq 5\)**
If \(\min(a, b)\) is less than or equal to 5, then the minimum of \(\min(a, b)\) and 5 is simply \(\min(a, b)\) itself. That is, \(\min(\min(a, b), 5) = \min(a, b)\).
Substituting this into equation (A), we get:
\(\min(a, b) = 3\).

**Case 2: \(\min(a, b) > 5\)**
If \(\min(a, b)\) is strictly greater than 5, then the minimum of \(\min(a, b)\) and 5 is 5. That is, \(\min(\min(a, b), 5) = 5\).
Substituting this into equation (A), we get:
\(5 = 3\).
This statement is a contradiction. Therefore, this case is impossible.

Since Case 2 leads to a contradiction, Case 1 must be true. Thus, we have established that \(\min(a, b) = 3\). This means the shorter of the two legs is 3.

Now, we proceed by considering two subcases, based on which leg is the shorter one:

**Subcase A: \(a \leq b\)**
If \(a \leq b\) and we know that \(\min(a, b) = 3\), it implies that \(a\) must be 3.
We use the Pythagorean theorem \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\). Substituting \(a=3\) and \(c=5\):
\(3^2 + b^2 = 5^2\)
\(9 + b^2 = 25\)
Subtracting 9 from both sides:
\(b^2 = 16\)
Since \(b > 0\), we take the positive square root: \(b = 4\).
Now we can calculate the area:
Area = \((1/2) \cdot a \cdot b = (1/2) \cdot 3 \cdot 4 = (1/2) \cdot 12 = 6\).

**Subcase B: \(b < a\)**
If \(b < a\) and we know that \(\min(a, b) = 3\), it implies that \(b\) must be 3.
We use the Pythagorean theorem \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\). Substituting \(b=3\) and \(c=5\):
\(a^2 + 3^2 = 5^2\)
\(a^2 + 9 = 25\)
Subtracting 9 from both sides:
\(a^2 = 16\)
Since \(a > 0\), we take the positive square root: \(a = 4\).
Now we can calculate the area:
Area = \((1/2) \cdot a \cdot b = (1/2) \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = (1/2) \cdot 12 = 6\).

In both subcases, we find that the area of the triangle is 6.

Therefore, the area of the triangle is 6 square meters.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The longest side of a right triangle is 5 meters and the shortest side is 3 meters. What is the area of the triangle in square meters? -/
theorem algebra_16243 (a b c : ℝ) (h₀ : a > 0) (h₁ : b > 0) (h₂ : c > 0)
    (h₃ : a^2 + b^2 = c^2) (h₄ : c = 5) (h₅ : min (min a b) c = 3) :
    (1 / 2) * a * b = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_16243 (a b c : ℝ) (h₀ : a > 0) (h₁ : b > 0) (h₂ : c > 0)
    (h₃ : a^2 + b^2 = c^2) (h₄ : c = 5) (h₅ : min (min a b) c = 3) :
    (1 / 2) * a * b = 6 := by
  have h6 : min (min a b) c = 3 := h₅
  rw [h₄] at h6
  have h7 : min a b = 3 := by
    by_cases h8 : min a b ≤ (5 : ℝ)
    · -- In this case, min (min a b) 5 = min a b
      have h9 : min (min a b) (5 : ℝ) = min a b := by
        apply min_eq_left
        linarith
      rw [h9] at h6
      linarith
    · -- In this case, min (min a b) 5 = 5
      have h10 : min (min a b) (5 : ℝ) = (5 : ℝ) := by
        apply min_eq_right
        linarith
      rw [h10] at h6
      linarith
  cases min_cases a b with
  | inl h9 =>
    have ha : a = 3 := by
      linarith [h9, h7]
    have hb : b = 4 := by
      rw [h₄] at h₃
      rw [ha] at h₃
      nlinarith
    rw [ha, hb]
    norm_num
  | inr h9 =>
    have hb : b = 3 := by
      linarith [h9, h7]
    have ha : a = 4 := by
      rw [h₄] at h₃
      rw [hb] at h₃
      nlinarith
    rw [ha, hb]
    norm_num

soln_description:
30.1. The given equation can be represented in the following form:

$$
\left(2 x^{2}-5\right)^{2}-7 x^{3}-13 x=0
$$

It is easy to see that the left side of the equation will be positive for any negative $x$, i.e., it cannot be equal to zero for any negative $x$, which means that the given equation does not have negative roots.
informal_statement:
30.1. Prove that the equation

$$
4 x^{4}-7 x^{3}-20 x^{2}-13 x+25=0
$$

has no negative roots.

$$
(7-9 \text { th) }
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 30.1. Prove that the equation

$$
4 x^{4}-7 x^{3}-20 x^{2}-13 x+25=0
$$

has no negative roots.

$$
(7-9 \text { th) }
$$ -/
theorem algebra_109807 (P : Polynomial ℝ) (hP : P = 4 * X ^ 4 - 7 * X ^ 3 - 20 * X ^ 2 - 13 * X + 25) :
    ∀ x : ℝ, P.eval x = 0 → x ≥ 0 := by

soln_description:
When $k \leqslant x \leqslant k+1(1 \leqslant k \leqslant 2016)$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{k} i(x-i)+\sum_{i=k+1}^{2017} i(i-x) \\
=\left(k^{2}+k-2017 \times 1009\right) x+ \\
\frac{2017 \times 2018 \times 4035}{6}-\frac{k(k+1)(2 k+1)}{3}
\end{array}
$$

is a linear function, and its minimum value is attained at the endpoints of the interval $[k, k+1]$.

Thus, the minimum term of the sequence $\{f(k)\}(1 \leqslant k \leqslant 2016)$ is the desired value.
Notice that,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(k+1)>f(k) \\
\Leftrightarrow k^{2}+k-2017 \times 1009>0 \\
\Leftrightarrow k \geqslant 1427 . \\
\text { Hence } f(x)_{\min }=f(1427)=801730806 .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
9. (16 points) When $x \in[1,2017]$, find
$$
f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{2017} i|x-i|
$$

the minimum value.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 9. (16 points) When $x \in[1,2017]$, find
$$
f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{2017} i|x-i|
$$

the minimum value. -/
theorem algebra_115340 (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ x, f x = ∑ i : Fin 2017, (i + 1) * |x - (i + 1)|) :
  IsLeast {y | ∃ x ∈ Icc 1 2017, f x = y} 801730806 := by

soln_description:
Proof: We first prove a lemma.

Lemma: For all real numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{2 k+1}$, we have
$$\left(\sum_{0 \leq i \leq k} x_{2 i+1}\right)^{2} \leq \sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq 2 k+1}\left(x_{i}+\cdots+x_{j}\right)^{2}$$

Proof: Let $s_{i}=x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{i} \quad i \in\{1,2, \cdots, k\}$, then
$$\sum_{0 \leq i \leq k} x_{2 i+1}=s_{1}+s_{3}-s_{2}+s_{5}-s_{4}+\cdots+s_{2 k+1}-s_{2 k}$$
The left-hand side of (*) can be rewritten as
$$\sum_{i=1}^{2 k+1} s_{i}^{2}-2 \sum_{i, j} s_{2 i} s_{2 j+1}+2 \sum_{i<j} s_{2 i} s_{2 j}+2 \sum_{i<j} s_{2 i+1} s_{2 j+1}+2$$
The right-hand side of (*) can be rewritten as
$$\sum_{i<j}\left(s_{i}-s_{j}\right)^{2}=(2 k+1) \sum_{i=1}^{2 k+1} s_{i}^{2}-2 \sum_{i<j} s_{i} s_{j}$$

Thus, the inequality is equivalent to
$$\begin{array}{l}
2 k \sum_{i=1}^{2 k+1} s_{i}^{2} \geq 4 \sum_{i<j} s_{2 i} s_{2 j}+4 \sum_{i<j} s_{2 i+1} s_{2 j+1} \\
\Leftrightarrow \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq k}\left(s_{2 i}-s_{2 j}\right)^{2}+\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq k}\left(s_{2 i+1}-s_{2 j+1}\right)^{2}+\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq k} s_{2 i}^{2} \geq 0
\end{array}$$

This is clearly true.
Returning to the original problem, we need to prove that for any subset $S \subset\{1,2, \cdots, n\}$, it is obvious that if $S$ has no separated elements (i.e., $S=\{i, i+1, \cdots, j\}$), then the conclusion is clearly true (since all terms on the right-hand side appear in the left-hand side). Assume $S$ is composed of some separated "segments", i.e.,
$$S=\left\{j_{1}, j_{1}+1, \cdots, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{3}+1, \cdots, j_{4}, \cdots, j_{2 m+1}, j_{2 m+1}+1, \cdots, j_{2 m+2}\right\}$$

Let
$$\begin{array}{l}
b_{1}=a_{j_{1}}+a_{j_{1}+1}+\cdots+a_{j_{2}} \\
b_{2}=a_{j_{2}+1}+\cdots+a_{j_{3}}
\end{array}$$
$$\begin{array}{l}
\cdots \cdots \\
b_{2 k+1}=a_{j_{2 m+1}}+a_{j_{2_{m+1}+1}}+\cdots+a_{j_{2_{m+2}}}
\end{array}$$

According to the lemma, using the notation $\sum_{i \in S} a_{i}=\sum_{j=0}^{k} b_{2 j+1}$, we have
